flow.informationArchitecture: Filtered categorical view. Educational explanation precedes data table. Columns represent specific risk dimensions (validation method, data availability, exit mechanism, failure scenarios).
frictionPoints: Many columns with technical terminology requires domain knowledge
Color coding (red/orange) requires color perception to distinguish risks
Small info icons may be easy to miss on first viewing
progressIndicators: Selected filter tab highlighted
Category count badges show number of protocols per type

copy.headline: Risk Analysis

microcopy.text: Rollups are L2s that periodically post state commitments to Ethereum. These commitments are validated by either Validity Proofs or are accepted optimistically and can be challenged via Fraud Proof mechanism within a certain fraud proof window. Additionally L2 data is also posted to Ethereum, hence there are no additional trust assumptions introduced.
microcopy.purpose: Educate users about Rollups before viewing risk data

microcopy.context: Exit Window and Sequencer Failure columns
microcopy.purpose: Indicate no delay/failure mechanism for this parameter
Explain mechanism and timeout for sequencer failure recovery

dataFormatting: Color indicators: Red 'None', Orange '7d', Normal black text
trustSignals: Detailed security mechanism descriptions (Fraud proofs, Validity proofs)
Specific timing parameters for each protocol
Clear labeling of execution delays and challenge windows

copy.headline: Data Availability

microcopy.text: Rollups are L2s that periodically post state commitments to Ethereum. These commitments are validated by either Validity Proofs or are accepted optimistically and can be challenged via Fraud Proof mechanism within a certain fraud proof window. Additionally L2 data is also posted to Ethereum, hence there are no additional trust assumptions introduced.
microcopy.purpose: Explain Rollup data availability model before showing details
Specify where and in what format data is posted
Describe what data is stored and if compressed

dataFormatting: Ethereum / Blobs or Calldata (dual option notation)
State diffs / Compressed (data type with processing indicator)
trustSignals: Explicit DA Bridge mechanisms (Enshrined, built-in security)
Data type transparency (Transaction data, State diffs)
Proof system variants (Optimistic, Validity) clearly labeled

copy.headline: Data Availability

microcopy.text: Validiums and Optimiums are L2s that, similarly to Rollups, periodically post state commitments to Ethereum that are validated by it, however data is not posted to Ethereum. This means that additional trust assumptions, external to Ethereum, are introduced to prevent data withholding attacks.
microcopy.context: Info panel above Validiums & Optimiums tab
microcopy.purpose: Educate user on the distinction and risks of this L2 category

dataFormatting: Column names: uppercase with icons (# NAME PROOF SYSTEM DA LAYER DA BRIDGE RISKS TYPE OF DATA)
trustSignals: Explicit trust assumption disclosure in microcopy
Categorization into Rollups, Validiums/Optimiums, Others (implied risk tiers)

copy.headline: Data Availability

microcopy.text: Others are L2s that either lack a working proof system or don't provide sufficient external DA guarantees (i.e. at least 5 independent attesters, a high enough threshold, or a proper DA bridge). To be listed in this category, the L2 must enshrine deposits from L1.
microcopy.purpose: Define risk criteria and inclusion threshold for this category

dataFormatting: Data types: 'Transaction data', 'State diffs', mixed compression flags
Risk indicators: visual bar charts with 4-color palette
trustSignals: Transparent risk disclosure: rows with 'None' DA Bridge highlighted visually
Specific threshold language: '5 independent attesters', 'high enough threshold'

copy.headline: Liveness

microcopy.text: Liveness shows how actively different operators are posting data to Ethereum and whether there are any significant deviations from their usual submission schedule. Please … Show more
microcopy.purpose: Explain what Liveness metric measures and its importance
Indicate the time bucket for aggregated metrics below

microcopy.text: TX DATA SUBMISSIONS / PROOF SUBMISSIONS / STATE UPDATES / PROOF SYSTEM / 30-DAY ANOMALIES

copy.headline: Costs
copy.subheadline: Onchain Costs tracks the fees paid by L2s to Ethereum for posting transaction data, proofs, and state updates. These costs provide insights into the economic efficiency of different solutions.

microcopy.purpose: Educational: explains what rollups are and how they post data

copy.headline: Okto

microcopy.text: This is an upcoming project. Stay tuned!
microcopy.purpose: Sets expectations; prevents confusion about live status

microcopy.text: An L2 designed to streamline blockchain complexity across multiple layers, including wallet, transactions, chain, data, and liquidity.

This project is currently in development. Once live, it will be listed along with comprehensive information about the risks and the technology. Follow us on Twitter to stay updated on the latest news regarding this and other projects.
microcopy.purpose: Educational: explains roadmap and directs to updates channel

trustSignals: Clear 'upcoming' status messaging prevents misleading impression of live product
Links to external resources (Website, Docs, Repository) build credibility
Detailed description of project purpose shows substance
Transparent communication about development status and roadmap
emptyStateText: Coming soon (displayed in Data Availability diagram)

copy.headline: Governance
copy.subheadline: By delegating your governance votes to L2BEAT, you're supporting our mission to protect the interests of the Ethereum community and uphold our shared values. Together, we can lead the L2 ecosystem towards a safer, more secure decentralized future.

microcopy.text: If you'd like to see us act as a delegate in another protocol, please let us know and we'll see what we can do.
microcopy.purpose: Invites community feedback and suggests openness to expanding delegation scope

microcopy.text: To promote transparency and communication as delegates, we're hosting recurring Office Hours on Google Meets.
